TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract beforefieldinit DynamicDocumentPaginator extends System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator
Public MustInherit Class DynamicDocumentPaginator Inherits DocumentPaginator

Docs.summary: Provides an abstract base class that supports automatic background pagination and tracking content positions across repaginations in addition to the methods and properties of its own base class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks By default, a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator> will automatically pre-paginate content in the background (this process begins when <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.IsBackgroundPaginationEnabled%2A> is `true`, which is the default setting).
When <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.IsBackgroundPaginationEnabled%2A> is `true`, the layout will also be repaginated due to changes in content or changes in <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator.PageSize%2A>.
The <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationProgress> event occurs upon completion of pagination (or repagination) of one or more pages, such as in the following situations:
- <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationProgress> events occur as content is paginated in the background. Depending on the implementation, the event may occur upon paginating one or multiple pages (<xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs> specifies which pages have been paginated).
- Calls to <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator.GetPage%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator.GetPageAsync%2A> may cause an <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationProgress> event to occur if the page specified has not been paginated. For example, if background pagination is enabled (<xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.IsBackgroundPaginationEnabled%2A> = `true`) but pagination has only been completed up to the third page, a call of <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator.GetPage%2A> with an argument of 6 will cause pages four, five, six, and seven to be paginated. Upon completion, a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationProgress> event will be raised with <xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs> settings of <xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs.Start%2A> = 4 and <xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs.Count%2A> = 4.
- With background pagination enabled (<xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.IsBackgroundPaginationEnabled%2A> = `true`), a change in <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator.PageSize%2A> on flow-format content, such as a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument>, may cause repagination and associated <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationProgress> events. Note that <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator.PageSize%2A> has no effect in repagination on fixed-format content, such as <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FixedDocument>, where the visual page size does not affect the layout.
A <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationCompleted> event also occurs when background pagination is disabled. For example, if there is only one page of content and <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.IsBackgroundPaginationEnabled%2A> = `false`), calling <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator.GetPage%2A> with an argument of 0 will result in two events:
1. A <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationProgress> event with <xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs> settings of <xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs.Start%2A> = 0 and <xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs.Count%2A> = 1.
2. A <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationCompleted> event.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If pages prior to the `contentPosition` have not been formatted, they will be paginated synchronously prior to returning the requested page number.
<xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberAsync%2A> provides similar functionality as <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumber%2A>, but with asynchronous operation.

Docs.summary: Returns the zero-based page number of the specified .

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void GetPageNumberAsync(class System.Windows.Documents.ContentPosition contentPosition) cil managed
Public Overridable Sub GetPageNumberAsync (contentPosition As ContentPosition)
abstract member GetPageNumberAsync : System.Windows.Documents.ContentPosition -> unit override this.GetPageNumberAsync : System.Windows.Documents.ContentPosition -> unit

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.param: The content position whose page number is needed.
Docs.summary: Asynchronously, returns (through the This method raises the event) the zero-based page number of the specified .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The only way to cancel the asynchronous operation of this method is to cancel all asynchronous operations. Contrast this with the other overload of this method: <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberAsync%28System.Windows.Documents.ContentPosition%2CSystem.Object%29>.
This method raises the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberCompleted> event. The page number is passed to the event as one of the event arguments. See <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberAsync%28System.Windows.Documents.ContentPosition%2CSystem.Object%29> for how to use this method to get the page number.

abstract member GetPageNumberAsync : System.Windows.Documents.ContentPosition * obj -> unit override this.GetPageNumberAsync : System.Windows.Documents.ContentPosition * obj -> unit

Docs.param: The content position element to return the page number of.
A unique identifier for the asynchronous task.
Docs.summary: Asynchronously, returns (through the This method raises the event) the zero-based page number of the specified .

remarks.format:
## Remarks This overload of the method makes it possible to cancel this asynchronous operation without cancelling all asynchronous operations.
This method raises the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberCompleted> event.
The following steps illustrate how to retrieve the page number of a given `contentPosition` asynchronously.
1. Create a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.GetPageNumberCompletedEventHandler> delegate and add it to be notified of <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberCompleted> events.
2. Call <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberAsync%28System.Windows.Documents.ContentPosition%2CSystem.Object%29> specifying the `contentPosition` desired and a unique `userState` object that will be used to identify the asynchronous task.
3. When the event occurs and the delegate is called, compare the event's <xref:System.Windows.Documents.GetPageNumberCompletedEventArgs>.<xref:System.ComponentModel.AsyncCompletedEventArgs.UserState%2A> property with the original <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberAsync%2A> `userState` parameter.
4. When the <xref:System.Windows.Documents.GetPageNumberCompletedEventArgs>.<xref:System.ComponentModel.AsyncCompletedEventArgs.UserState%2A> property matches the original <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberAsync%28System.Windows.Documents.ContentPosition%2CSystem.Object%29> `userState`, the operation is complete and the page number is ready. (The <xref:System.Windows.Documents.GetPageNumberCompletedEventArgs>.<xref:System.Windows.Documents.GetPageNumberCompletedEventArgs.ContentPosition%2A> property will also match the original <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberAsync%28System.Windows.Documents.ContentPosition%2CSystem.Object%29> `contentPosition` parameter.)
5. The <xref:System.Windows.Documents.GetPageNumberCompletedEventArgs>.<xref:System.Windows.Documents.GetPageNumberCompletedEventArgs.PageNumber%2A> property contains the zero-based page number of the specified `contentPosition`.
<xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumber%2A> provides similar functionality as <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.GetPageNumberAsync%2A>, but for synchronous operation.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool IsBackgroundPaginationEnabled { get; set; }

member this.IsBackgroundPaginationEnabled : bool with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether pagination is performed automatically in the background in response to certain events, such as a change in page size.
Docs.value: if background pagination is enabled; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks When `true`, pagination is performed in the background, raising <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationProgress> and <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationCompleted> events as appropriate.
Pagination of <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FixedDocument> content, as distinct from a <xref:System.Windows.Documents.FlowDocument> is not affected by changes to the visual <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator.PageSize%2A>.

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event PaginationCompleted As EventHandler

Docs.summary: Occurs when all document content has been paginated.

remarks.format: ## Remarks When <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DynamicDocumentPaginator.PaginationCompleted> occurs, <xref:System.Windows.Documents.DocumentPaginator.IsPageCountValid%2A> is `true` until a new pagination is initiated.

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event PaginationProgress As PaginationProgressEventHandler

Docs.summary: Occurs when one or more content pages have been paginated.

remarks.format: ## Remarks <xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs> properties <xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs.Start%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Documents.PaginationProgressEventArgs.Count%2A> identify the range of pages paginated.
